Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Functional and fun shooting design; great enthusiast-oriented feature set; very nice photo quality
Cons: Should be a little faster shot to shot.
Bottom Line: The Canon PowerShot G10 is a solid enthusiast digital camera for those who want something compact to complement a dSLR.
Canon PowerShot G10
Panasonic's Lumix DMC-G1 offers interchangeable lenses, Nikon's Coolpix P6000 provides GPS--the feature sets on enthusiast compact cameras are all over the place these days. So, should we be disappointed that the whizziest new feature of Canon's PowerShot G10 is its almost-15-megapixel resolution? While this isn't the kind of update that will inspire envy in G9 owners or a must-have feature to experiment with, the Canon G10 holds true to the elements that have mad ... e the G series a successful shooter's camera over the years.
The G10 is physically quite similar to the G9. At 14 ounces, it's heavier by about an ounce, and it's also a bit bigger--one- to three-tenths of an inch on all sides, for dimensions of 4.3 by 1.8 by 3.1 inches. As with its predecessors, the Canon G10's metal body feels like a tank. I'm beginning to wish for just a little bit more grip, though, especially since the thumb rest feels kind of slippery.
The dial configuration ranks as the most no ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Very good photo quality (in good light and at low ISOs); Nice 5X zoom lens with 28 - 140 mm range; Optical image stabilization; Solid, well built body, with easy-to-access ISO and exposure compensation dials; Generally snappy performance; High resolution 3-inch LCD display; good low light visibility; Full manual controls, with plenty of scene modes too; RAW image format support; Customizable menus and buttons; Very expandable: supports an external flash, remote shutter release cable, conversion lens, and underwater case; Redeye not a problem thanks to automatic removal tool; Well implemented face detection feature -- handy face self-timer feature; Built-in neutral density filter; Fancy playback mode Movie mode now supports up to 50 mins of continuous recording; Strong battery life ...
Cons: Lots of noise reduction in low light -- images get noisy quickly in good light after ISO 400; No white balance bracketing or fine-tuning; Continuous shooting mode won't win any awards for speed; Lack of HD movie mode a disappointment; Design annoyances: top dials easy to bump accidentally - small shutter release/zoom controller - thumb sits right on the focus point button; Can't swap memory cards while using a tripod; Still missing the fast lens and rotating LCD of G-series cameras past
The Canon PowerShot G10 is a very capable fixed-lens camera that does just about everything right. It's fast, well built, customizable, and expandable. Unfortunately, it's biggest problems relate to image quality, specifically to noise. Canon threw the highest resolution sensor they could find into the G10 (14.7 Megapixel), and they've had to apply a lot of noise reduction to keep noise in check. While photos look very good at low ISOs, things go downhill rapidly, especially in low light. I can recommend the PowerShot G10 to those who plan on keeping the ISO relatively low. However, if you're a high ISO or low light shooter, it's probably worth stepping up to a digital SLR. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
We reviewed the PowerShot G9, this camera's predecessor, last year.
The Canon PowerShot G10, then, has been over a year in the pipeline and yet on the face of it, the new camera isn't so very different from the old one.
But there are some significant differences. The one that's likely to grab the most headlines is the G10's increase in resolution, offering a 14.7 megapixel sensor where the G9 had 12 megapixels.
Actually, though, that's probably the least important difference. Numerically, it's not very much at all and, besides, pixel densities this high bring serious noise (and noise reduction) issues as we've seen so many times before.
Improved lens
Instead, one of the most useful improvements in this camera is the switch from the old camera's 35-210 ... mm equivalent 6x zoom to a shorter-range 28-140mm lens.
Yes, it's a drop from a 6x zoom to a 5x zoom, but you get a proper 28mm equivalent wide angle rather than the half-hearted 35mm equivalent of the old lens.
There are other differences on the top of the camera. The G9 had an ISO dial at the far left, but on the G10 this has now been placed under the main mode dial to the right.
On the far left there's now a handy EV compensation dial. And it really is handy. The ability to adjust the ISO and the EV compensation so readily is like a breath of fresh air.
RAW power?
There are two other things worthy of special attention. One is the RAW mode... and it's not just the fact that the G10 has one, but that this camera can shoot and save RAW files as quickly as a DSLR. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
The Canon Powershot G10 has 14.7 megapixels and a wide angle, 5x optical zoom lens. It is one of the most advanced compact digital cameras you can buy. In fact I can't think of one that is more advanced. It has a full set of manual exposure modes, plus extra options for flash and focusing.
Why Buy the Canon Powershot G10? The Powershot G10 is very impressive. It has Digital SLR features, great picture quality and the design of the camera puts key features at your fingertips. The build quality is top drawer and the LCD screen is of the highest quality.
Image Quality Outdoor 1 (Medium Zoom) The Powershot G10 takes great photos. Focusing is excellent. This is true both in the centre of the photo and out at the edges. The brickwork on the building in the middle of thi ... s test shot is more or less pin sharp, while the name on the boat towards the left hand side of the photo is also easy to read. The colours pack a punch too, with strong blues and greens.
Outdoor 2 (No Zoom) Despite the fact that the Powershot G10 has a wide angle lens this is still a sharp photo. Digital cameras with wide angle lenses can create photos that lack sharpness when the lens is not zoomed in at all, but this camera outperforms the pack.
Outdoor 3 (Maximum Zoom) This is another example showing sharp focus. I can pick out roof tiles, plus plenty of detail at the widest points of the photo. All in all my test shots have been very encouraging so far.
Outdoor 4 (Building) This is the sharpest set of outdoor scenic shots I have taken in all the years I have been testing compact digital cameras. The definition in the photos is excellent and as I have mentioned above the levels of sharpness at the edges is outstanding.
Outdoor Portrait With this photo I would like to have seen that bit more colour in the shot. Aside from that this is another sharp photo and you should be able to take high quality general portrait photos. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
The 14.7Mp Canon PowerShot G10 is a stylish-looking compact camera.
There's something appealing about the Canon PowerShot G10's old-school rangefinder styling, and the little lights that glow orange next to the old-timey ISO and EV compensation dials.
What's more, the Canon PowerShot G10 is a solidly built point-and-shoot that packs some advanced camera features to attract digital SLR users looking for a second, smaller camera for everyday snapshots.
The Canon PowerShot G10's cool factor is no doubt a reason for its high price tag. Also, it seems to be Canon's newest attempt to win the megapixel war: the G10 is a step up from its predecessor, the 12Mp PowerShot G9. The benefits of the increased pixel count are dubious, however, as I saw in my tests.
Visit Photo ... Advisor for the latest reviews of digital photography and video hardware and software, cameras and accessories. PLUS: get tips and tricks to improve your photos
Like the G9, the Canon PowerShot G10 offers RAW shooting options, including RAW+JPEG. It also incorporates a wider-angle lens (28mm equivalent), which worked well for my landscape shots. Unfortunately, Canon has correspondingly reduced the zoom to the telephoto equivalent of 140mm, with a 5X optical zoom as opposed to the 6X optical zoom on the G9.
That may be a letdown for some people, but take heart: Lens teleconverters are available separately, and the G9's hot shoe has been carried forward onto this model.
On the Canon PowerShot G10, Canon offers its handy My Menu feature, which stores favorite settings for recall at any time. The camera's image stabilisation mode let me make at least a few shots that we couldn't have captured otherwise, such as handheld shots of ferns in the shady New Zealand area of the botanical gardens.
The camera menus are easy to navigate after a few peeks at the manual. Common point-and-shoot features, such as face recognition, scene modes, and stitch assist for making panoramas, are on board, too.
The Canon PowerShot G10's assortment of modes includes auto, program, and shutter and aperture priority, as well as the option to go fully manual. You determine manual exposure on the LCD. A small meter appears, and below it are the camera's current exposure settings. Everything is neatly displayed, and you can easily adjust the settings using a thumbwheel on the camera back.
Things get complicated, though, with manual focus, and we quickly decided never to use that option again. On the Canon PowerShot G10's LCD, a small window within the full image appears, and you adjust focus - again using the thumbwheel - based on a bar displayed on the right edge. Having the manual-focus option is nice, but the implementation here is a bit kludgy.
Thankfully, the Canon PowerShot G10's autofocus handled most situations well enough.
The Canon PowerShot G10's battery life is superb. In our Test Centre evaluations, it fired off 456 shots on a single charge, better than nearly any point-and-shoot we've tested.
ISO ranges from 80 to 3200, but regrettably noise and soft focus made an obvious impact on images at ISO 400 and up. Sometimes we even observed chromatic noise at ISO 100 in darker areas. And unfortunately, the Canon PowerShot G10 is often slow and inaccurate in focusing, particularly in low-light situations.
You must be patient with this camera and wait until the focus indicator says 'ok'; otherwise the shutter will fire, and you won't get a sharp photo. In well-lit outdoor scenes, on the other hand, the Canon PowerShot G10 did just fine, and thanks to the RAW option, you can recover a lot of invisible detail.
This Canon PowerShot G10 has a good macro mode, enabling you to get 1cm from your subject. Sometimes here the camera will cast its own shadow on the subject and you'll have to back off, but some of our macro shots looked very good. The bulk of our test images, shot in a botanical garden, were punchy and vivid, but not unrealistically oversaturated. The Canon PowerShot G10 seemed to offer a pleasant boost of saturation compared with the Canon PowerShot SX10 IS, which... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: The Canon PowerShot G10 is still going to be the benchmark by which all other high-spec compacts are measured, but it's no longer the top dog. It is beaten on picture quality and portability by the smaller, lighter and slightly cheaper Panasonic LX3, and is beaten badly on value for money by most entry-level DSLRs. It's still an impressive camera and can produce excellent results, especially in Raw mode, but the price means its appeal is a little too specialised for some. Watch the video review This seems to be happening a lot lately, but it's exactly a year and a day since I reviewed the Canon PowerShot G9. Time and technology march ever onwards, so today I'm taking a look at the G9's successor, unsurprisingly named the PowerShot G10. Actually it's not as predictable as all that, because ... for reasons too arcane to discuss here there was no G4 or G8, so this is actually the eighth model in Canon's flagship pro-sumer compact series. Since the launch of the G1 in 2000, the G series has been the benchmark for high-spec compacts, and the G10 raises the standard even higher. It features a powerful 14.7-megapixel 1/1.7-inch CCD sensor, a large 3.0-inch wide-view monitor with a class-leading resolution of 461k dots, and a 5x zoom image-stabilised f/2.8 - 4.5 lens with a 28mm-equivalent wide-angle setting (the G9 has a 6x zoom equivalent to 35-210mm). It has a full range of manual exposure controls, Raw mode shooting and the same DIGIC IV image processor as Canon's latest digital SLRs. Of course a specification like that doesn't come cheap, and the G10 is currently selling for around £340, although some retailers are charging over £400. This is significantly more expensive than most entry-level DSLRs. /786ec4|4ee1_9559-canong103quart.jpg The air is pretty thin up there at the top of the compact camera market, and G10 doesn't have a lot of direct competition. Its closest competitor is the fantastic Panasonic Lumix LX3 (£313), but anyone shopping for a high-spec compact will also want to consider the Nikon CoolPix P6000 (£307) and the Ricoh GR Digital II (£354). /b41ab4|903c_9559-canong10front.jpg At least the G10 looks like it should cost a lot of money. It's a large and imposing camera, measuring 109.1 x 77.7 x 45.9 mm and weighing approximately 380g fully loaded, around twice the size and weight of a typical pocket compact. It's also a few millimetres larger and around 30g heavier than the G9. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I brought this camera after a recent trip to the snow and found my Olympus U725SW seriously lacking through the lack of a viewfinder. I didn't want to lug around an SLR, so had to squint and cross my fingers while trying to frame up the shots. When I first picked up the Canon G10 I was amazed at how heavy it felt. Not like a brick, but solid. This is one serious camera. The finish is excellent and it is well balanced in the hands. My wife picked it up and said Wow! Can I have this camera? She was particularly impressed when I plugged it into my Canon printer and produced a high quality print straight from the camera, shot in RAW. I know this is not new, but it is the first time I felt that this function is relevant. Shooting with a DSLR. the images are shot with a purpose or image in mind ... , so adjustments in Lightroom and Photoshop are almost mandatory. Shooting with the G10 is fun and spontaneous, which are the images most suited for adding to the photo album. I haven't had a chance to put the camera through its paces yet, and I am still waiting to try out some of the new functions, particularly the i-Contrast. What I do like is that this camera is just like picking up a Canon DSLR. The menu, controls and functions are almost identical. It was a very comfortable feeling to grab the camera and almost instinctively know how it all worked. The screen size is huge, and the information it displays is complete, without taking over the screen. The display showing the aperture and shutter adjustments pure genius. What I like most about this camera is that I now have a professionally built compact with a great zoom range, RAW, and heaps of Mpx that I can take almost anywhere. It fills the space between my wonderful little underwater Olympus and my superb but bulky DSLR's. Not only that, but with all of the Auto settings, it is a camera my wife and kids can use as a point and press. (The first time I haven't been grilled over a camera purchase)! Watching the green square on the screen that follows the faces around to focus is amazing, and the green beam that is emitted to pre focus with the flash is like something out of GhostBusters! I'm looking forward to trying out all of the other myriad of features, such as the movie mode, custom settings and the self timer for group shots. For the life of me though, I can't ever see myself coupling up my twin flash macro system. I'm pleased to say that this camera has lived up to my expectations, and apart from the lack of a CMOS sensor, I can't foresee any reason to upgrade for many years to come. This is a beautiful piece of gear and is well worth the money. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Reviewer: Steve, editor of The Other Pages
Item.ReviewTitle: Great Compact Camera for Event Photos
Item.Review: I was looking for a serviceable replacement for my well-traveled Canon S2IS, and chose the G10 because of its mid-range zoom and the positive comments on its image quality I received from a fellow photographer. I use the camera for family, macro, travel and wildlife photography, but frequently get volunteered to take photos for music events ranging from stage concerts to parades to marching band competitions. I take an average of about 1,200 photos a month. The G10 does a great job in low light with its high ISO range, and does a better job controlling the flash intensity than past Canon cameras I have owned. It also handles the high contrast of stage lighting well. While the G10 does not have the unique zero focal length macro of the S2, S3, or S5 cameras, the 10.1 mega pixel image size ... makes up for it. You can still resolve the eye spots on a snail or catch all of the threads in a spider web. The small size (compared to a DSLR), moderate weight, and excellent battery life also make this a good travel camera. The combination of a large LCD and an optical viewfinder is a plus. The only negative I have observed is a problem handling very bright point source lighting in video mode. Stadium lights or sunset reflections over water come out fine in photos, but there are vertical white bands in video mode. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I use the camera for all around photography. I shoot macro for jewelry applications and I also use is to shoot houses for real estate. The Primary reason I got the G10 is because I wanted the versatility of manual ISO and Fstop adjustments. I can also adjust timing etc. Drawbacks... no open bulb timer.. which means I cannot keep the shutter open for as long as I like (fun with nightime shots), although there is a 15 second setting which is pretty much long enough for most applications. The screen is fixed and doesn't rotate around for different angles, which also means it doesn't have a fixed safe position. I used to have this on my Olympus C5060. The screen does however have a relatively big size. It only has one memory card slot, not two. I cannot, as of yet, directly download pics wi ... thout installing the software (pet peeve). It only has one other lense attachment, I would like to see a fish eye produced. It doesn't have a remote control, but the timer seems pretty easy to use. It takes a little while to process shots too. I did the research and found it was the best all around (sturdy too) camera for what I wanted, which is a lot. I haven't used nearly half the applications/settings the camera has but I love it. Not only that.. lol.. everywhere I go anyone who knows anything says O nice G10. Anyway I love the camera and know there is more room for me the grow with all the applications, but don't take my word for, do your research and good luck with whatever you buy. =) [)o] mg expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This camera appears to be the designers' reaction to the limitation of ever smaller cameras. Every design constraint for small cameras seems to have been ignored in this one, and if the size is not an issue for you, the result is a really great camera.(It is an nice oppposite for my 14 meg, very compact Lumix DMC FX-150.) This camera has a huge battery that seems to last forever. It has a viewfinder style window (with diopter adjustment!) , great in sunlight when all LCD screens are at least a little hard to see. You can turn this LCD screen off. It has a built in flash and a shoe for flash as well. Big lens and 14.7 meg for clear detailed shots and a great zoom. Lots of heavy duty knobs rather than nested menus so it is easier to adjust when quick adjustment is called for. A labelled ... button for flipping pictures from vertical to horizontal! Some small negatives that do not make me regret the buy. The pop up flash or night protrait setting is not accessible through the flash menu, instead through the scenes menu, unless I simply have not figured it out. Second, I have not been able to use Photoshop to work with the RAW ouput of this camera, and there seem to be other with the same issue on the discussion groups on the web, but I am certain that Adobe will get around to fixing that - this is a very new design. Why RAW formats have to get changed all the time for each new camera is a mystery, not this camera's problem particularly. The included software is painfully slow at converting RAW to JPEG, but it does have a batch mode. On the other hand, if you get the settings right it will save both JPEG and RAW. This was not the easiest process (I got it wrong the first time and got only RAW), but possible without reading the manual - my acid test. Really a pleasure to handle this, feels good in your hands, very solid feel, well balanced. And still lighter than an SLR equipped with a similar capability lens. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Overall this appears to be a good camera with one major shortcoming- the viewfinder - which according to Canon only covers 77% of the actual image. The viewfinder is similar to an older rangefinder type viewfinder i.e. a direct view over and generally including the lens. It is not an electronic viewfinder which would show the actual framing of your photo. Since my personal preference is to use the viewfinder as opposed to the LCD screen I find this to be a major drawback in the camera design. In order to use the Lcd screen one must hold the camera out at a distance. Using the viewfinder allows one to brace the camera squarely against your body thus reducing the potential for camera movement and allows exact framing of the shot. I imagine for casual shooters who wish to hold the camera at ... arms length, the LCD screen is appropriate, however for anyone who shots through the viewfinder this is a very significant problem. One other small but not insignificant annoyance is the lack of contrast control in the operating software. I have found Nikon software contrast control to be of immense value in controlling the the values in a picture which then can be later adjusted to optimum curves using photoshop or similar programs. Far as I can tell there is no option for same with the G10 software. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Built like a brick (in a good way). Has RAW and all the other features I wanted in a anywhere backup camera, when either space/time or site restrictions won't let me carry the main. Everything is wonderful so far, but two features. One I want, but its unusual so I'll mention it. To take a picture, you need a gentle 1/2 push to focus, then the remainder to take the pic. This allows you to focus on one object, pan, then frame for another area. Its activatable as one of the control functions on other cameras like the Rebel. But it does take some getting used to. You can't just swoosh and hammer down the plunger for focus/picture all in one motion. If it sounds bad, I'm just not explaining it well, believe me, its a great feature. The one thing I haven't mastered yet, is manual focus ... . Hard to pick one leaf out of a plant with the little scrolly wheel to focus with. Its possible you can vary the size of the focusing box, and I just haven't gotten that far yet. For the times I don't want to carry around the Rebel Xti with extended base battery pack and external flash. . . its the backup I've been waiting for. Lightroom 2.0 doesn't support the RAW yet, but their included PC software will convert RAW to TIFF for now. (Adobe has promised the upgrade any time now for RAW.) So (as God intended) I can shoot RAW now, and improve it later when the new software comes along. Its just what I wanted. You'll enjoy it. Well placed and easily accessible controls. jkh expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Pros: Easy to Use, Good Battery Life, Good sized screen, Great Resolution, Great Zoom, Nice Features and Settings ... Cons: Not Good In Low Light I bought this camera to replace my Canon Powershot A640, which I loved. This G10 camera has loads of features above it. It's an amazing camera and rivals SLR image quality. The images have amazing color and clarity. The only thing that could replace this camera for me is a high quality DSLR. I primarily use this as a family camera for personal use and vacationing, but as a designer I find it useful to take artistic shots that are incredible. It has many features and I love the custom settings so that I don't have to reset the settings I often use (such as auto balance & macro with no flash; the auto settings usually have auto flash). I'm able ... to turn it on and quickly take the shot I want without having to take time to change settings for flash, focusing mode, etc. I've used this to be able to take quick close ups of our young son with the continuous shot mode previously set so we don't ever miss a smile. AMAZING! If you are familiar with Canon menus and navigation of the buttons, this camera should be relatively easy to learn. Even being familar with Canons for several years, I've had to adjust to a few things. The scrolling wheel on the back of the camera took a little time for me to get used to, and it's a bit difficult to use when you are trying to shoot and focus one-handed. However, when I use it for focusing I'm usually closing in on a close up object, so I'd have to steady the camera with both hands for those shots anyhow. The G10's grip leaves something to be desired. When wielding it with one hand I worry about slipping in my grip and ending up with a crooked shot. The shutter button is also less substantial than my older Canon cameras, but it's raised a bit more so it's easy to find when taking a quick shot. The 14.7 megapixels makes it possible to cut and crop photos to exactly what you want. The cropped photos can be enlarged and still retain great image quality. The G10 makes it possible to capture every single eyelash on my son's face. It can even pick up the individual dust specs on the table in Macro mode. The things I was looking for in my replacement camera that I had to sacrifice with the purchase of the G10 were an articulated multi-angle LCD screen and use of AA batteries. The articulated LCD comes in really handy for taking shots above a crowd or at other odd angles, but this camera sadly doesn't have it. The super bright LCD on the G10 is very clear compared to my previous camera and can be viewed at more of an angle than many other LCD screens, but it isn't able to move off the back of the camera as some Canon cameras allow. Something I had to settle for, but in the end is worth it. This G10 still has an incredibly high quality LCD screen. As far as lacking AA batteries, I have really not noticed after having the G10 for several months now. The G10's battery life is incredible. I rarely have to charge the battery, and I keep a spare battery ready so I never miss a shot. Older Lith-ion batteries weren't as good, but this is an excellent battery, able to keep up with the demands of the camera. The only cons I've experienced with the G10 are issues with use in low light and with flash. If you are skilled with custom settings of shutter speed and ISO, you may be able to compensate for this. I find that quite often even in moderate indoor light, there is still a blur on moving objects. When using the flash indoors, the subject is often blown out and overexposed. These are things that a little adjusting in the settings can fix, but they are problems that many less-experienced people may have trouble with. Overall I'm incredibly happy with this purchase and look forward to having this high quality camera for many years. Even as other cameras catch up in quality, this G10 will still be great. The G10 has become my #1 camera now. There is no contest. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I'm an new photographer and got this camera to continue learning on as a new compact that I could carry everywhere but still be able to shoot better shots than a regular point and shoot can do. This camera fits my needs so well. I'm still learning how to get the most out of it, but the shots I've already taken with it have been well worth the money. I really love the size, the color swap feature,and color accent feature. Very fun features to play with. The only thing that really bothers me is that the viewfinder is false. Kinda annoying when the sun is really out and you can't see the lcd screen. Otherwise this is a great camera for people just getting the feel for photography.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Canon quality, but too many mega pixels
Item.Review:
Pros: excellent photos; rugged construction; easy to use; hot shoe
Cons: a bit more expensive than others
Canon has built a reputation in the top end point and shoot category and there has not been much competition from others such as Nikon. The power on time for the camera is reasonably fast, but not as quick as a "slider" style camera could be with an internal zoom lens. This model captures images on the 1/1.7 inch CCD type at a maximum of 14.7 mega pixels. In the mega pixel war, I think this has gone too far. There is no real need to have this many mega pixels in a camera with such a small image sensor. The high mega pixel count also diminishes the low light capability of the camera as can be seen in shots with a film type graininess. However, the handling of the camera is ... quite nice with physical dials to switch modes, exposure compensation and ISO speed. You can feel the ruggedness of the camera, which is as good as you can get in the point and shoot category. Having a hot shoe to add a flash is also very useful. Overall, this is a good camera, but it suffers from having too many mega pixels that reduce the image quality. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Canon G10 makes for a perfect DSLR substitute.
Item.Review:
Canon's G series have always been a hit, generation after another they find ways to improve them and the G10 continues that upward trend. It offers a fix wide angle lens and a usable optical zoom. It's higher pixels allows for stronger images when you have to use the digital zoom. The G10 also gives you very usable and powerful manual mode options. The build quality is unsurpassed, as it's built like a tank.
It's big enough so it won't be accidentally dropped but small enough so it fits in your pockets. While being so compact, it does not lack any quality. It's image sensor is bigger than that of the average point-and-shoot camera. The body is mostly metal and it looks and feels very strong.
If you're traveling and don't want to lug around your DSLR suitcase, you can easily p ... ut this in your pocket and with careful composing, you can create very professional and quality photos.
With all of this you can still take decent videos too. Although HD abilities would makes this a superb package. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Full-featured point-n-shoot with convenient controls
Cons: Certain conditions image is noisy, price
I wouldn't recommend this camera to a novice. This is a full-featured point-n-shoot, and was made for the serious amateur or professional who wants full control of their images.
As a professional, I carry the G10 with me all the time now. Even when shooting for a client, my G10 is close by. And, with a hot shoe, I can use my flash equipment with the G10. It is a great emergency stand-by camera and all around camera.
If you have been waiting for a 35-mm style range finder, this camera is it. The controls enable you to change your bracket factor (-2 to +2) via a knob on the top of the camera. You can also change the ISO via a knob. This means, no menu futzing ... for those two settings. The shutter and f-stop can be change by the thumb wheel at the back of the camera.
What is really cool is when changing the shutter and f-stop, the LCD display shows the settings much the way the view finder would on an old rangefinder.
If you are not shooting under ideal lighting conditions, like most digital cameras you will get noise. I've read some of the other reviews where users complain about "image quality". All I can say is, they must have had the camera set for a high ISO, under exposed, or used some other setting that cause excess noise.
Being able to shoot RAW is also a huge factor in my purchasing this camera. Using RAW mode in conjunction with Adobe's Lightroom is a nice advantage over other high-end digital point-n-shoots that only shoot jpegs. RAW mode allows for adjustment of settings without changing the original capture. Thus, you always preserve what your camera captured as long as the RAW file is intact.
If I were asked what single thing I would change about the G10 it would be to allow for f-16. The f-8 limits some flash and brigh-light use. Other than that, technically it has most everything else one would want.
There are a few minor things that can be frustraiting, however. First, the power button is positioned such that it is difficult to activate with glove ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Easy To Use; Comfortable Controls; Great Picture Quality; Bright LCD; Strong Construction; Easy Setup
I was looking for a camera that has great picture quality and is easily transportable...not bulky like the SLR's. After much research and hands-on I found the Canon G10 to be an excellent choice. The G10 is lightweight, but solid feeling, with user friendly dials and many features and modes for creative and fun shooting, including Macro. It is easy to use right out of the box on auto settings, but has many features found in more sophisticated equipment, including shooting in RAW. The picture quality is great. The G10 is small enough to fit in a purse or jacket pocket, so I am able to take it everywhere easily. The battery is long lasting, you can edit within the camera, an ... d also shoot videos. Although the LCD is large and bright I wish it folded out and rotated for more shooting options like my old camera. The zoom is not as much as I would like but the wide angle is great and the 14.7 megapixel allows me to crop in and get a good shot of a distant subject. The hot shoe is a big plus for flash control. This is a great camera. I love it!!! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Easy to understand, Great picture quality/features
Cons: Expensive, Small zoom lens
This camera was a great purchase. It is extremely easy to just point and click, and the features are easy to understand. The picture quality is outstanding. I'm sure you could get a better camera if you spend a grand, but for the price, this seems like a professional camera. This camera doesn't have a huge zoom lens, but that's not really what I was looking for in a camera. The rechargeable battery feature is nice too. Overall, this is a great camera, even if it is a bit pricey.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Canon G10 is exactly what I needed!
Item.Review: I am a photographer at a large church. I need a camera that I can put into a holster and whip out when needed. Many rooms, including the sanctuary, are dimly illuminated. I have been shooting with a tripod and taking time exposures at ISO 400. Now I can shoot without a tripod, at ISO 800, with better results, and shoot 10 pictures in rapid fire in the time it used to take to make one picture. White balance is no longer an issue, the G10 corrects automatically wherever I shoot. The 28mm wide angle allows me to shoot in small rooms or get the entire sancturary in the frame. The 5x zoom and digital zoom allow telephoto shots almost anywhere. The 14 megapixels allow extreme cropping that I could never do before. This is a camera that has everything going for it, even wired remote cont ... rol that fires every time. The lens automatically caps when the camera is turned off. Also has great video mode with Quicktime format. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: High Resolution for great features
Cons: High Price at the lens provided
A wonderful camera that comes ready to start shooting. Just grab it and go on your dream trip. Keep everything in memories and print them too. This is a nice alternative to big SLR camera while giving high quality shoots. Definitely expensive but worth it for users looking to shoot on high zoom and larger landscapes from a distance or on the top of a hill. But still big to carry around in daily lives. It is considerably larger and heavier than other comparable cameras from Sony and Olympus. Definitely must have for a photographer looking to edit the photos and getting large prints. The great use in print-prduction because of its RAW IMAGES along with a true manual mode, both of which are musts for ... professional photo editing. Along with a fantastic chip processing near to real-life colors it comes with face detection and anti vibration too. In brief a wonderful camera with pro-features which can be user even by anyone. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Pros: Versatile and powerful The G-10 Canon produces outstanding pictures. With easy to use (many)optional settings it is a superior camera. Of course having a old fashioned view finder is important for outdoor pics in bright light. The wide-angle lens is also a plus. I have made several 20"X30" poster prints from pictures taken at 80 ISO (using a custom setting) and there were sharp and balanced. I also value the electronic filter which I used with the above custom setting for outdoor scenic pictures. All in all the G-10 is a very powerful camera in a compact size as well.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This is my first 'own' camera, but have been taking many many photos with friends/ families cameras for years before. I wanted, and still do, a DSLR, but decided to go with a little less mainly because of costs. After much research this is what i came up with, for a camera with similar DSLR power, w/o expensive interchangeable lenses. I am extremely happy with this camera. It is small enough to bring along anywhere, yet large enough for that substantial, confident feel. Low light is slightly lacking, with a little more noise in higher iso than I like to see. I have only shot about 10 out of 700 pictures in auto, and I love the ease of changing settings in manual mode (with the scroll wheel and easy navigation) compared to with many compact digitals with annoying menus set up mainly for t ... he auto user. The colors and quality of the images are amazing!! I havent shot as many action shots as I would have liked to yet, but the scenic pics from fall time have been amazing. The std. wide angle on the camera is great when shooting in tight spaces. I plan to get the tele converter later down the road for outdoors. The std tele is ok, and the digital zoom clears up wonderfully, but I do find that in some instances I wish it had more tele, mainly when shooting RAW and dont have the digital zoom back up. Very solid build and construction, I am extremely protective of my gear, and I like not having to worry about every time I set it down. The strap slot should be bigger to accommodate different strap clips. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Bought this camera for my wife and to compliment my 40D & 20D DSLR's, for the times I don't want to drag camera bag, bodies and lenses around for a day. It meets my wife's needs of a simple camera, with viewfinder, but also has all the features of the DSLR's that I use in a small package. The quality of photographs is equivalent to the DSLR's that cost thousands of dollars more.
The camera is extremely simple to use in auto modes, but the menu system takes a little getting used to when using the manual modes.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I recently bought a Canon G10 for recreational photography. I have been very happy with the camera. The G10 has complete manual capability, great portability and ease of function for point and shoot modes. I have only owned Canon digital and film cameras and am very pleased yet again. The G10 is powerful, well built, and versatile. I would recommend this camera for extreme enthusiasts and professionals. I took this camera on a recent trip to NYC and was very pleased with the results I got. There are many reviews complaining about noise levels at low light conditions/high isos. I agree that there is a good amount of noise when used in these conditions. However, I did not find it very bothersome. For the size, image quality, and price the G10 is easily the best point and shoot came ... ra on the market. I also own the lens adapter/lens. It doesn't increase focal length too much but a nice addition nonetheless. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Great quality at a great price
Item.Review: I bought this product a couple of weeks ago to take with me on a vacation through Europe. Since there are so few negatives, I will start with those. The camera is a bit heavy and the digital zoom is grainy - I dont recommend zooming past the optical zoom. That being said, the picture quality is amazing, it is very easy to use, and once you get the hang of the manual elements you can take professional-looking pictures in nearly any environment. It is a good size and I kept it in my purse the whole trip so I would always have it with me. Even though it is a bit heavier than I would like, I have been carrying it around NY to spontaneously take pictures. The heavier weight makes it very solid which can be a plus. It looks professional and retro and people constantly comment on how nice it lo ... oks. The large screen is great and the video quality is very good as well. My boyfriend, a semi-professional photographer, started using my camera instead of his during our trip since the pictures were of equal quality to the bigger SLR he had brought along. The battery life is exceptional and currently I have gone 10 days taking more than 600 pictures and have not charged it. Overall I would recommend this camera to anyone who wants a point-and-shoot that can be operated manually for artistic photos or in special environments. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I use the Powershot G10 as my re-entry camera and my carry camera. I have not lugged around an SLR kit in 15 years, but I remember well the inconvenience of it all. After considering a DSLR for my re-entry to photography, I realized that a carry camera might be more versatile while in the canoe, on the bike, and just to have on my person. I have utilized the G10 for several hundred images including landscapes, flowers/macro, insects, tourist shots, and general use. I find the controls to be intelligently placed and easy to master (I have a Canon DSLR for work use). The G10 has many different settings with which to experiment, and surprisingly it does a great job in it's programmed modes. The resolution is very good. I stick with ISO 200 or lower, as others have mentioned significant ... noise above that. I do not use the viewfinder, the display is wonderful. I am very pleased with the feel and quality of the camera, and feel I got a good value for my money. The unit fits my mission well. I would like to see additional zoom capability, so I gave it 4 stars. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I recently purchased this camera for my trip to Hawaii. I wanted something that gave me the options my dslr gives me without the weight and the bulk. And I gotta say, I really liked it! There are a few things I'm not crazy about (the noise levels when you shoot anything above 400, the spot metering and the long recycle time) but over all I am very impressed. The controls are very similar to other Canon cameras and the picture quality for a point and shoot is superb. I wouldn't use it to replace my 5d and I still found myself using my 5d while on vacation just not as much. All in all, it is a very good camera for the value.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Pros: Great LCD Screen, Quality feel, Quick power on, Very user friendly ... Cons: Memory card location Having been a life long Nikon user (and partial to their lenses for image quality) - I was in the market to upgrade from my last digital (almost 3 yrs). My previous issue with Nikon was power on time and shutter lag as well as little "user" control, especially in low light situations. Having researched a number of upper-end P&S options, the Canon seemed to continually come up amongst the best picks. Canon is very quick and responsive when powering on as well as providing the user with full manual control. For low light levels - it also has a hot shoe for a top mounted flash. The LCD is very impressive (and has a "gyro" that rotates images when viewing). Quality has been highly impres ... sive. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Pros: Good macro mode, Great image quality, Large LCD screen, Looooonnnnng battery life, RAW images ... Cons: Slow maximum aperture I own a Canon 40D DSLR with several lenses but bought the G10 because its small(er) size and lighter weight make it an easier camera for on-the-go shooting. Image quality is quite good with minimal noise, distortion and vignetting across the zoom range. The ability to save RAW image files offer much greater postprocessing control to compensate for exposure and color defects. I still use the 40D for work shots but for pleasure and recreational use, the G10 provides the ability to produce images of comparable quality in a much smaller package. Built-in Image Stabilization dramatically reduces camera shake at low shutter speeds. Battery life is simply the best I' ... ve yet found. My G10 is sitting here next to me and hasn't been recharged since late June. Despite shooting over 300 images at a wedding last weekend, it still shows nearly a full charge. The zoom range in the G10 skews more towards the wide angle end than in the G9 but sacrifices considerable magnification in the telephoto end. I'd prefer to see Canon develop future models with a wider zoom range lens instead of larger image file sizes. I'd also like to see a wider ISO range and faster maximum apertures to better function in low or marginal lighting conditions. Also missing in the G10 was the G9s slick interval shooting option, enabling images to be shot automatically at preset intervals. While the G10s ergonomics and operation are well thought out and reasonably intuitive, it's worth emphasizing that this is a complicated camera that's probably not appropriate for technophobes or casual users. But in the hands of a willing student, it's probably the best Point & Shoot camera available today. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This is a high quality, well built camera capable of taking excellent quality photographs. I have been using it for about 2 months now and have taken it to Japan and Australia. Prints from a 3800 on VFA are simply stunning. I apply Ken Stones recommendations to begin with and they work very well, although I don't use the Vivid color mode. The top dial exposure compensation is a great convenience. I haven't had this much fun using a camera in years. There are only 3 draw backs that I have been able to find: Unless you shoot in RAW the only color space for jpegs is SRGB-it would be better to have ADOBE RGB as the color space; There is No Bulb setting-even with the wired remote; I purchased the 270 ex external flash-unless I'm doing something wrong, after you set your flash compensation, if ... you review your shots (who doesn't?) the compensation doesn't stick when you go back into shooting mode, it would be better if you didn't have to reset it after each review. (if I'm missing a setting please let me know) The LCD is really good-your pictures will never look as good as the LCD. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I direct a small group of video producers and photographers at a major public university. We have a large arsenal of Nikon D2X and D2H cameras and lenses for normal use, but I wanted something small that could be easily carried. The Canon G10 makes beautiful images. The combination of automatic modes along with dedicated controls for ISO and exposure compensation provide great control. The addition of an easy to operate manual mode makes this a powerful tool. I bought one for each of my staff to carry with them at all times.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Image quality is the name of the game
Item.Review: I am a landscape photographer and use the G10 primarily as a back up to my 5D. It is also used as a travel camera to take meaningful and unique photos rather than the standard tourist fare. It's manual controls and RAW capability facilitate that. However, if you need to hand it to someone to take the quick picture of me with the big fish or the Elvis look-alike, just set it on Auto and it performs marvelously. Autofocus and shutter delay is tolerable, but slow like all point-and-shoots. You don't want to try to shoot breaching whales or hummingbirds, but it is fine for most shots. The color balance and rendition is excellent! Especially in RAW, and quite brilliant in JPEG. It is sturdily built and if you are familiar with Canon menus on their other DSLR's or point-and-shoots, you'll ... be comfortable with this camera. A few of the features like face recognition and i-Contrast are tricky, but easy to learn with a little practice. The battery performance is excellent. If you have a backup and charger, you set for weeks of travel without a problem. As reported elsewhere, low light performance is medium and ISO above 400 gets pretty grainy. Noise reduction programs can do wonders up to 400 and make tolerable up to 800. Higher is....well, pretty messy expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Strong Construction; Great Picture Quality; Comfortable Controls; Bright LCD
Very full-featured and powerful camera in a tiny package. I got this as a backup to my DSLR, but after seeing the image quality and easy portability, it may become my primary shooter. Excellent image quality you'd expect from a Canon, very solid build-quality, nice controls. I especially love the macro focus and movie modes.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Nice Features and Settings; Great Resolution; Great Zoom; Easy to Use; Good sized screen; Good Battery Life; Excellent in Low Light
Bought this to photograph structural features of buildings for insurance work. It is great, it has all the manual controls necessary to get great shots in low light. I picked this camera, because it seems like it has enough extra manual features to be close to a DSLR, however it is about 1/2 the size and weight. Also thought this would be a great first step towards a DSLR if I thought I needed one down the road. Right now this will be perfect for my needs.
The first battery charge lasted about 3 weeks, with me using it about 1/2 hr/day, still on second battery charge!
AND, Adorama offers a great package!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: As easy to use as you want and suitable for all skill/interest levels. Enough practical features for a semi-pro. Only slight disappointment is the image quality - could have been better, especially as nearly 15MP. Amazing that no memory card whatsoever included! Screen is brilliantly big - but proud of body so will easily scratch/damage if camera laid down on back. Best price I could find anywhere at the time.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Nice Camera, But not for moving subjects
Item.Review: I had really high hopes for this camera. The first one I received had a dead pixel in the rear LCD display. After ten-plus years of purchasing digicams, this was the first time I've ever encountered a flaw like that. Kudos to B&H for a quick and seamless return process. Once I received the replacement, I ran approx. 150 test shots through it under various lighting conditions. Low light performance wasn't as bad as I'd heard, although higher ISO certainly produced more noise than lower ISO's. The controls were logically placed and I loved the knobs on the top. Once familiar with the controls, you can very quickly make adjustments and tweaks to shooting modes and exposure. The build is top notch. This camera feels very sturdy and fits my hand more comfortably than any other PS. I ... have an older 2MP Powershot A series and this is actually smaller than that one. Canon is really packing a ton of features into smaller bodies. My primary issue with this camera is shooting moving subjects. This camera takes stunning photos if your subject is perfectly still in adequate lighting, however, if the subject is moving, you might have some issues. several photos of my kids and my dog had motion blur, even at close range with flash. Autofocus also wasn't as quick as I would have liked. I realize this can be corrected with manual adjustment, and I've played with settings to produce gorgeous portraits of my kids. However, if I'm running around an amusement park trying to snap pics of constantly moving subjects, I don't have time to keep making manual adjustments. Photos also tend to sometimes show unacceptable noise when enlarged to the highest resolution. Raw shooting gave great results and the included Canon software gives you good editing control over raw images. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Great for those who want more control.
Item.Review: Pros: Good Image Quality, Good Image Stabilization, Great Zoom, Large Clear LCD ... Cons: Cost, Heavy vs other ps, Lag / Shutter Delay, No HD Video This is a great camera for those who want more options than just standard point and shoot. I am learning more about photography and adjusting camera settings; the G10 provides a great platform to do that without spending a lot of money on a SLR. I have some friends who are formal/pro photographers who use this camera as a "grab and go" they can always carry with them, and/or take to places where it is not practical to lug around all of their SLR equipment. It also has the capacity to shoot in RAW format, which is a great feature. One of the things I didn't like about this camera is the time between shots. Compared to other point and shoots, it ... is slow, unless you are in one of the more quick shooting modes. It usually is not a big issue, but it can be annoying at times. The G10 is also heavier and bulkier than many of the point and shoots out there. It will not fit in a pant or small shirt pocket, but it is small enough to carry around in your purse or bag. The sturdiness of the build does have it's advantages; I have dropped mine more than a few times, and it is still working great! It is disappointing that Canon still has not put HD video on their cameras. If you are planning on shooting a lot of video, I would look elsewhere. Added Note: I have since upgraded to the G11(better in low light), but have given my G10 to a friend. She absolutely loves the quality of the photos it takes, even in auto mode! If you have a G9 and are looking to upgrade, I might say that you would do better to upgrade to the G11 vs. G10. However, for most casual photographers, the differences between the G11 and G10 are not significant enough to necessitate purchasing the newer version. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Pros: Can add lenses, Easy To Use, Excellent image quality, Large Clear LCD, Nice Body Color, Quick charge battery ... Cons: Not an SLR I owned the G7 and upgraded to the G10 (passed the G7 into open arms of my daughter!). I must say that I LOVE my camera. This camera has great features, huge quality and fits in most decent sized purses/bags; no not in your jeans/shirt pocket. It is not a SLR which seem to be all the rage but I one of the reasons that I love this camera is that it has HUGE power without the HUGE size. I have GREAT photos from this camera. Reading the entire user manual will increase the appreciation of the features packed in this camera. It's more than a just a point and click!!! After buying the G7 in 2007 and now the G10, I continue to be amazed with the image quality! T ... he ability to use the more advanced features/settings or go with all auto is great; sometimes I want to be more creative and other times I just want snapshots of friends and family. I highly recommend this camera and haven't had any problems with it at all. Use iMac to process images. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Flash is adjustable; Great Picture Quality; Convenient to Carry; Easy To Use; DSLR-like Controls; Strong Construction; Comfortable Controls; Easy Setup; Bright LCD
Cons: Low light noisy; Flash needed in low light
Bought this as a backup for my 5D. Great camera to carry around and convenient to take on vacation. Has many same/similar controls and features as Canon DSLR's. LCD is bright, has high resolution, and is easy to read even in daylight. Picture quality, resolution, color, contrast in daylight and well-lit night situations is superb. Low-light no-flash shots are no match for a good DSLR, but adjustable flash exposure works well at night. Flexible controls and settings let anyone from beginners to pros take great photos. Would highly recommend this to any photo ent ... husiast, serious amateur, or pro. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: My Use: Backup to EOD 40D, as well as a larger pocket camera to bring with me on trips, to meetings. I'm a designer and photographer, and take loads of pictures for a variety of needs. Overall review: Camera performed amazing so far. Love quick change on all manual settings (ISO, shutter speed, apeture). Quick change white balance, etc. RAW format and high quality images. Problems: Photos at higher ISO's and in low light conditions have significant noise when compared to a digital SLR, but performs competitively in ideal conditions or with a flash. The big setback is that you have to use canon's software to extract and read the RAW file and then send it to Photoshop in either TIFF or PSD format. I found a way around this by updating Lightroom to the newest version, which include ... s the drivers to read the G10's RAW format. Didn't understand why Lightroom made the updated but not Photoshop, but guess that's Adobe's logic. I'm sure down the road this will be fixed. I love this camera so far, and really happy with it. Recommended. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: The camera you'll always keep at hand!!
Item.Review: Professionally I use a Canon 5D with pro lenses and such, but this camera makes me feel spoiled. It's truly the most intelligent point and shoot out there. The controls make it easy to adjust ISO and compensation for the perfect shot. The large LCD screen gives you a live preview of the exposure based on your settings. And has a handy live histogram too. The face detection is amazing. I held the camera up and panned it around the room at Christmas time and it picked up any and every face immediately as it came into the frame. The macro capabilities are really impressive too! It opens up photo ops that you never considered with another point and shoot. It's a 28-140mm equivalent focal length is more width than any point and shoot I've ever had. A nice touch when you run out of room t ... o back up when you're taking a group shot. And it shoots RAW! It's maybe more than pocket-sized, that might be the one downfall I see at this point, but the pay off is well worth it. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Comfortable Controls; Great Picture Quality; Easy To Use; Bright LCD; Strong Construction
I've read some reviews that dont favor the G10. I dont agree. I have used DSLRs exclusively the past few years and I got this camera as a light weight alternative for hiking and rock climbing. Its a great camera and I am very happy with it. The image quality is simply the best of any compact I've tested. I dont need it to do ISO 800+ and one handed operation is a must for my application. The image stabilization is superb, giving me a few more stops at ISO 80, and also works well to make movies very smooth. The controls are very easy to use and very well thought out. I'd like an even wider lens but at 28mm it is working well so far. HD video would also be nice.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Only a few months prior, I bought the G9 for my wife as a camera that she could enjoy taking snapshots with while I was working on our vacations. It was such a sweet, sophisticated camera that I kept hogging it. I'd never before used such a satisfying point-and-shoot camera. When the G10 came out, I quickly sneaked a purchase. The wide-angle lens is a nice addition. (It would've been nice if they'd bumped the HD video feature from 15 fps rather than eliminating it altogether, but that's not what I bought the camera for.) Shooting with RAW, I find the image quality and the portability to be an astonishing combination. As a 35-year veteran of film & dslr cameras, I'd never had much experience with live view LCD framing. Now I see the virtues (and am looking forward to purchasing ... the 5D Mk II when it becomes available). I think that this camera is changing my shooting style, because it is so ready to bring and to use anywhere and everywhere -- without fear that I'm going to get a great shot with an inferior image. And it isn't simply a point-and-shoot; this camera has a deep well of creative options to use at-will. As a long-time serious &/or professional photographer, I'm very impressed. (Assignment to self: Use only the G10 for a year.) expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Amazing camera - I can't put it down
Item.Review: I have 2 old Canon Point and Shoot cameras - an ancient 2MP Elph and a 5MP G5 - both still work perfectly after all these years so you know I like and trust the brand. When I went to the big Javits photo show, I had a chance to handle the new G10 and while I need another camera like I need $4 a gallon gas, I fell in love and just had to have one. I have been using mine for a couple of weeks and can't believe how good it is. While it has an optical view finder, I have become addicted to the huge, bright screen for all shooting. It's much easier on my myopic eyes, even in bright sun. The zoom range is pretty good but the real attraction for me is the 28mm wide angle end of the range. For groups and pictures in tight spaces (I go a lot of grip and grin shots for magazines) it's a life saver ... . I plan to use it like I used to use my Leicas - a pro-level always with me camera. The battery life is good. The power of the flash is good too - I like the feature that lets you pick the shutter speed so you can set the speed slow enough to pick up ambient background light. That's right - no more black backgrounds with flash! The old P&S bugaboo - shutter lag - has been tamed with the G10. It's not as perfect as my M4, but it's pretty darn close. Finally, image quality - JPEG or Raw - is very good. Color is good too - I think the optics are first rate. I plan to use it as a backup for my DSLRs for magazine and travel photography. I recommend the G10 to anyone who wants a good camera - the images are pro quality. The build quality is excellent and based on decades of experience with Canon equipment (4 EOS cameras, 2 P&S, 1 video and a D40) I am confident that it represents good value. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Best all-around P&S on the market
Item.Review: If you're on the fence no need to be, this camera has some of the best image quality for any P&S under $500 on the market. If you need a wider angle or faster lens or do a lot of low-light photog then I would recommend the Panasonic LX-3. The reason to go for the G10 is better zoom range, higher pixels which do help for prints, and better software. The size of this camera is bigger than most P&S cameras but it is not bad. It's more of belt pouch-sized camera than pocket-sized. Those of us with large hands prefer the G10. Don't plan on using ISO higher than 400 unless in a pinch or willing to clean it up in post-processing. I use my Canon Speedlites with this camera to get the most out of this camera in the low ISO range. G10 is simply the best good light P&S on the mark ... et, my favorite street camera in good or average day light. For low light conditions you'll still need to rely on a dSLR. Pricey but I'm happy with the price-to-performance thus far. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: The Canon Powershot G10 is an awesome camera. It is a step up from a regular point and shoot but not quite at the DSLR level. Small enough to be portable yet very well built. The features and capabilities are tremendous. I love it because I use it as a backup camera to my DSLR and when I need to capture an unexpected great shot. This book by Magic Lantern Guides is well done. Lots of information, easy to read and nice visuals. It is so much better than the G10 manual.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This is my backup camera and very useful in terms of watching a concert that a professional camera is not allowed. But they should not include the JPEG file when you shot it in a RAW mode because this will eat your memory stick a lot. And also the color of the image in LCD screen is not the same when you download it into your computer??? you need to edit it into Digital Photo Professional Software, which is included in the package. Other than that??? it???s almost perfect!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Nice camera, but I returned it
Item.Review:
Pros: Rugged; Good sized screen
Cons: Low-Quality Pictures; Not Good In Low Light
I really wanted to like this camera. I have been searching for a decent small digital camera, so I don't have to lug my D700 everywhere I go. I always carry a camera and thought this might be perfect for times I don't expect to make photos. Well, while it appears very well made, has a very nice monitor, I just couldn't live with only f8 in manual mode (not sure about A or P mode), or the high Noise above ISO 400. Also, I'm a long time Nikon user and the controls just aren't up to the logic of Nikon. Take the manual mode, it has a nice dedicated knob to switch between modes but manual mode default is to adjust the shutter speed. To adjust the f stop took a lot of button-guessing, head scrat ... ching. Too many controls need the manual to operate. Maybe to Canon people it all makes sense.Any way, it went back, and my search for a digital Contax T2, or Nikon 28/35ti continues. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Fast Shutter Speed; Easy to Use; Great Zoom; Great Resolution; Large Clear LCD; Good Battery Life
I wanted a new camera this year and decided to buy last years G10 instead. When my passion to rediscover shooting manually again peaked, I decided to cash my birthday check before something around the house broke)and opted for a refurbished G10. I just wish I'd bought this camera sooner. Out of the box, the big, vivid 3" display was a welcome relief from not having to wear my readers. The battery life is incredible (around 400 plus shots). My old canon would eat double A's like candy. Additionally, the image stabilization is an big improvement, especially with the face detection. For my work I shoot interiors and use a auxillary light source, so shooting in low light conditions ... isn't a problem. Outside it no problem at all. Overall, the look and feel of the G10 reminds me of my old nikon and I love making choices with the top mounted mode dial. I love using and handling the G10 and look forward to discovering the possibilities that lie ahead. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Pros: Easy to Use, Good sized screen, Great Resolution, Nice Features and Settings Outstanding Quality... I have printed images to 20x30 with ourstanding results. It is a small camera with great features. I would strongly recommend it. I added an extra battery and have taken some photographs.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Liked it so much, I bought it again
Item.Review: This is my second G10 -- quickly replaced it after original was stolen (along with my Nikon DSLR) by a thug in Denver. Powerful camera in a compact package. Durable, solid build. I've taken the G10 with me on trips to the Dominican Republic, Iraq, and Korea, and used it as a backup at Yellowstone and Grand Teton. It's bigger than many point and shoots, and doesn't easily fit into a shirt pocket. But, it has great battery life, excellent image quality, OK (not great) low light performance, and is a perfect all-around travel camera.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Memory snappe with control over pictures
Item.Review:
Pros: Zoom Range; Strong Construction; Lots of manual control; Great Picture Quality; size
Cons: Poor Operation in Low Light
I like what it offers for the money in picture quality. It reasonably fast for general photography.
The IS and zoom range are good for most uses.
The controls are bit cramped and confusing after being used to SLR cameras. But one gets used to them. Low light performance isn't anything to cheer for, but a lot can be saved with software noice removal.
There is nice amount of control over exposure so it makes worthy camera even for pros who want something that fits in to the pocket.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I haven't learned about all of the great features of this camera yet, but so far, for simple point-and-shoot picture taking, I'm very pleased. I like the size and the weight and I love the giant screen.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This is a definitely a great compact digital, and all of the reviews I've read suggest it is as an alternative to a budget DSLR, but if you're looking for the image quality of a DSLR, this is not the right product for you. This camera is for the pro, or semipro photographer that doesn't want to carry around his heavy DSLR around all of the time. It gives you full manual control, which is my favourite feature, but struggles with colour rendition at anything above ISO 400. I would have like to have seen HD video capabilities. There are large gaps in the front of the lens that allow sand, and other dirt to get into the lens very easily.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I was a serious view camera amateur. Now, as a retired grandfather, I'm tired of hauling all that stuff around. With the G-10, I tinker and use all of the automatic modes as well as the manual mode. However, when I am rushed, I use AUTO and am rarely dissapointed. It's nice not to have to search around a menu for ISO settings; there's a handy knob on top. And for what it's worth, I shot over 400 photos with one charged battery on a recent trip to India. It's also nice to be able to record both a jpg and RAW at the same time. I don't always have time to mess with my digital photo software. The picture quality exceeds my expectations, the view screen is large and bright, even the movie clips are suitable for SD playback with animated slide show films. The rechargable battery lasts a ... long time, but find-em-anywhere AA's they're not. I bought a stand-by just in case. Once at a zoo in Singapore the low battery indication occurred. Not having a spare, I was worried. But as it turns out the battery lasted for the remaining 30 shots I took and didn't die. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I use the G10 when I don't want to carry around my 30D with battery grip and a bag full of lenses. It produces great quality pics when you don't want to be too conspicuous with a D-SLR but still need pro-level features. The only feature missing is a bulb shutter setting. Also, a nice quality wrist strap (along with the neck strap) would be nice. Absolutely a great camera and I have recommened it to friends who have since purchased the G10 (from B&H I might add). Would have given it 5 stars, but the shutter lag time could be shorter. Built like a tank. Controls are conveniently located and easy to use. Great feel in your hands.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Purchased this camera about a month ago and I've been attached to it since. I take it everywhere. Picture quality is awesome for the price. Still figuring out some of the more advanced settings, but I love the AUTO point and shoot. The pictures are so crisp and clear. I recommend this to anyone looking for a great camera to capture special moments and to take fun pics (color swap and accent color option is fun to play with).

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Strong Construction; Bright LCD; Easy To Use; Great Picture Quality; Easy to Keep Clean; Comfortable Controls; Easy Setup
Cons: Long Lag Time
I received this camera for my birthday (from the best sister in the world - if you're reading this, thank you again). I've only been using it for about 2 weeks but I'm already in love. I travel as much as possible and photograph everything from nature to people and landscapes to still life. I have high hopes for the G10. This is a serious upgrade from my 5 year old point and shoot. The image quality is superb, the wide angle lens is great for artistic/landscape shots, the image stabilization function works well, and the camera feels sturdy (although I wish it was weather-proof like my previous Olympus Stylus series point and shoot ... ). The camera has an optical viewer which is handy for desperate times of low battery and an optical zoom range of 5x! The only real downsides are that the camera is a bit bulky, the lag time between flash shots are a bit long and the zoom knob could also be bigger.Indoor shots without flash are good as long as you minimize shake. I've explored a few of the special scene/filters and the color accent function is interesting. Another plus is that Canon manufactures an attachable tele converter lens to increase the G10's zoom range by 1.4x. The camera is easy to use/set up and the functions are intuitive (for an intermediate digital photographer) - I haven't even cracked open the manual yet. Overall, I highly recommend this camera if you're looking for something better than a simple point and shoot but not as advanced as a dSLR. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: excellent photos; easy to use
I love my Canon Powershot! The picture quality is amazing, even when compared to more expensive point and shoot cameras that are available. Zoom quality is great, but I never feel as though I need to zoom because once I get onto my photo website, I can crop the pictures and the quality is upheld. The camera has a way to connect a tripod to it, as well as a timer. This camera can be used in many different ways, as it also has video capabilities. Also, the Canon Powershot is easy to use. The different modes are simple to use and self-explanatory. The Canon Powershot was recommended to me and when I first used the camera, I was impressed. I couldn't put it down and I couldn't stop playing with it, finding out new things about the camera. The Canon Po ... wershoot was definitely one of the best purchases I've ever made. It is definitely the best camera I have ever owned. I hope to upgrade when and upgrade is available, so I can stay on top of things! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: G10: Kudos, Canon, a Real Winner
Item.Review: This camera replaced my G9. (I own the D3 for my main shooting). I always have it with me in my center console of my car, though I need to remove it during the hot, summer months for fear of damaging it. The controls are the easiest and by far the best there are on any P&S. Immediate +- exposure compensation without fishing through a myriad of menus. Raw is a must for me as that's all I shoot. One of the few P&S that offer it, and the pics are phenomenal. I've done some rudimentary testing between it and my former 1DMKIII. I shot some scenery, some close ups of leaves on trees with blue sky backgrounds. While I didn't print them, I was hardpressed to tell the difference, and I don't believe anyone else could tell either. And I was using the Canon 24-70 L on the MKIII, a fi ... ne lens. Overall, I'd highly recommend this camera. The size doesn't bother me at all. I find it perfectly fitted to my hand, unlike the G9 which I had to buy an aftermarket grip for. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Easy To Use; Great Picture Quality; Strong Construction; Bright LCD; Comfortable Controls
Cons: Can't find any faults yet
I use the product to document my travels and photograph friends. I like the way it feels in my hands and its weight and its very bright LCD screen and that I can use an eye level viewfinder as well. Battery life seems quite good as well. Also, this is the first still camera that I have owned which allows me to zoom in video mode.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G10 14.7 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: screan size, endless features, the video feature is great!
Cons: nothing so far.
i love this camera! i read up a lot before purchasing a camera. i couldnt make up my mind on a nikon or a canon. im glad i made the choice i did. i have heard a lot of complaints about the nikons picture qualities.
